subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] To Paul
msgSnippet: Hi Tiny You are correct. CitationPronunciation is an alternate pronunciation of English used when we are attempting to make ourselves understood. Most educated
messageBody:
Hi Tiny
You are correct. Citation
Pronunciation is an alternate pronunciation of English
used when we are attempting to make ourselves
understood. Most educated people will use Citation
Pronunciation when explaining a new polly-syllabic word to the less
educated. Teacher to pupil as it were. 
It is quite useful for that purpose.
The problem with using Citation Pronunciation
to write with the Read Alphabet
is that pronunciation is dependant on a literary understanding
of English and is derived from the Roman letter spelling of
the English word.
The whole point of the Read Alphabet is that it is a replacement
for the Roman Alphabet, not just an adjunct or shorthand.
 
Let's go back to an actual nice clear English pronunciation,
not some
ideal pronunciation based on the old Roman Letter spelling.
I'd rather figure out a consistent accent, than an archaic
spelling.
Regards, Paul V.
__________________attached__________________________
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
From: Tinyallen@...
Date: Sat, 1 Dec 2007 15:33:55 -0800
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] To Paul

One common method to product phonemic writing (for
one's dialect) is to produce words in Citation
Pronunciation.
This is easy to demonstrate; suppose you'd used a
word your friend didn't know, so you pronounce it
slowly and distinctly with full pronunciation of all
vowels.
This is citation pronunciation, and using it will
make your QS clearer for others to read without
struggling through all those schwas the vowels mumbled
into.

While it's possible to give some flavor of dialect
in QS - and impossible to avoid entirely - I suspect
the extent won't much exceed normal TO misspellings.

--- Erik Felker <ejfelker@dslextreme .com> wrote:

> internal voice that
